body:
There are a few more things we can do:
- Try to use c++11's atomic to implement the spin_lock 
  - This may solve some ASM issues across archs
- Put things in namespace mxnet::common, heavily document all the class variables and functions in the header(refer to other headers in include)
  - So others can use it easily(we might move them to dmlc-core eventually)
Let us also loop @mli  in this on possibility of moving additional thread concurrency util into dmlc-core. we could possibly put them in include/dmlc/thread

For the spin_lock implementation, I think current implementation is quite
efficient. The "xchg" instruction is atomic instruction. I don't know
c++11's implementation. But why we need to use 11's atomic to implement
that?

On Wed, Jul 1, 2015 at 12:11 PM, Tianqi Chen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Let us also loop @mli https://github.com/mli in this on possibility of
> moving additional thread concurrency util into dmlc-core. we could possibly
> put them in include/dmlc/thread
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2#issuecomment-117731863.

## 

Minjie Wang
_New York University | Computer Science_
715 Broadway, New York, NY, 10009
@jermainewang  The major reason was portability. ASM can be tricky when you port it to different platforms, for example, a architecture that do not support x86
@mli I tried that some time ago. It was no faster that `std::atomic_bool`. But nevertheless we could use that implementation. I couldn't be worse.
@hotpxl  if the efficiency is the same. I would recommend using atomic, due to the reason I mentioned
@tqchen I was comparing `std::atomic_bool` to `std::atomic_flag`. I never tested `xchg`.
good change overall, i made a few minor comments, please fix them and then merge it in
close since this is moved to dmlc-core
Modified as we discussed last time.

I think the suggestions are good. One thing about `mutate_var` is, even if you need to READ and WRITE a variable, you should not put it into `use_var` once it's in `mutate_var`. The name `const_var` and `mutable_var` would be better in this sense.

`PushAsync` pushes a temporary operator. It's needed because I use it to delete an operator.

got it, so the difference is that 

the user need to delete the op in `Create & Push(op)`, while the system managers the op in `Push/PushAsync(func)`? i'm fine with that. another solution maybe always return `std::shared_ptr<OprHandle>`

Yes.

We actually have to do some work (push `OprHandle` into queue) before destructing it. So a destructor would not meet the needs.
Also renaming `DAGEngine` to `Engine`, in case I forget.
C style callback and PushAsync is done in #63
heads is renamed to outputs as #65 The rest of name will rename the same for now. so this is closed for now
fixed

Dispatcher is moved outside of lock scope in #67 
- I kept the write inside the scope, because the last attempt moving it out caused an error in the CI https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/builds/80173154
The dispatcher bug is fixed in #69 , now things all out of lock scope.
merged in #91
cc @mli @hotpxl
Will use GetSharedRef instead to ensure destruction order

It turns out there is another BUG in dispatcher, when things are outside lock scope. The code replied on `to_delete_`, which could change. 

The bugfix is in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/bd36bbc1c2a49924385489bcdbe63c71dbf8c559  introduced by #105
Yes, data format is same
cc @mli @antinucleon
Now fixed

when I update all the code, and run cifar10.py a few minute: the program is shuttdown
./mshadow/mshadow/./stream_gpu-inl.h:46: Check failed: (err) == (cudaSuccess) driver shutting down

Please pull newest version and try again. We don't release formally yet, MXNet is still under heavily construction. I just checked on my machine for 10 epoch without any error.

it's a known bug, it happens when the static cuda is deleted earlier than the static engine. hopefully tianqi will fix it today
I think Tianqi fixed it already
partially, there are still some corner cases
I try to update the code and submodule again but there is nothing to update...
Just pushed a fix to the master. Can you try again? Thanks alot for being early birds :) We know it is a bit harsh conditions in the beginning

I update and run it 30 minute  it not shutdown but hang up, cpu rate is 0%

I tried 5 times but no luck to repeat. Did you update all dmlc-core and mshadow?
Finally I repeat once. Thanks for letting us know
there is no trace when I ctrl+c

I update dmlc-core and mshadow every time.... there is a detail:my gnu 0 is error, and I use gpu index start with 1:
change line 128: gpus = [mx.gpu(i + 1) for i in range(num_gpus)]

A few more comments:
- Move the batching procedure into init
- Move doc of parameters of init into class docstring, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L414
cc @mli  @antinucleon  Context's string now becomes `cpu(0)` `gpu(1)`.
The problem was caused by error handling at program exit @junranhe  I pushed some fix to the current mast at #131 Can you pull and try again if it works for you?
ok now :)
Thanks!

now I run it with 2 gpu, and get message,what matter?
kernel:BUG: soft lockup - CPU#0 stuck for 23s! [ksoftirqd/0:3]
We have not seen this before, will your program able to proceed? Seems have something to do with the overclocking.
my program is able to proceed, and cpu rate is only 100%, and no iteration result,   when I run it with 1 gnu, cpu rate is about 170%, I have the other job to do,so I will test it again later...
have you overlocked your cpu? or you may check the temperature by `sensors`
I don't know where the cpu is overlocked... the temperatures are not over 50 C, and I run purine and cxxnet 3 gpu are no problem...

Could due to we use cpu too optimistically. I pushed a fix to the master to make thread allocation more conservative, maybe if you can try again to see if the problem occurs. How many cores do you have in your machine?
6 core
I update and try it again, never get bug message, but it just hang up on the first round, first train_data iertation, it seems hang up on load data
Pushed another fix, @junranhe  Thanks for being so patient with the new stuff. Can you try again?
I think is some error in my machine, when I remove the error gnu 0(but I never run on it), and restart machine, the bug is gone:)

in that case, you can look at the error in dmesg. if that gpu is broken, it
should have been reported some errors there (i experienced that before.. in
my case, even nvidia-smi was hanged )

Can you check your compiler version? We need g++-4.8
thanks, tqchen, that is the problem of g++ version. Now it is installed successfully

cc @mli  @hotpxl 

This improves the kvstore sync latency

Thanks for trying new tools. We don't finish all things in MXNet yet. We will make a detailed doc about how to train ImageNet. `data.py` is not for generating data but declaration of data iterator. The segfault is because DataIter didn't find the image rec file in path, We will make a more clear error info.

---

We hope to finish all docs and code in today or tomorrow.
The dataset information can be found here http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html

Thanks, now I come across an invalid pointer problem and it's difficult to debug. 
I will keep an eye on mxnet and try again after it is formally released.
We've already checked when GetPathInfo, but when the code runs into the check_fail, there will be a python error. Need check further.
Could due to the error was throw by a child thread that opens the data. The exception throw in the child thread could not be automatically catched by the master thread
cc @hotpxl

Interesting, Thanks for investigation! There is nothing that I am aware of preventing us using function pointer instead of std::function. This might due to the fact that the registered ScalatSetValueOp was an inline function. 

I updated the code in #160  Please check the updated code after it merged in

We will deprecate CXXNET today. However MXNet is quite different to CXXNet. MXNet is more flexible and efficiency than CXXNET. We are still working on some final doc. Please check out [doc](https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq.html#what-is-the-relation-between-mxnet-and-cxxnet-minerva-purine2) and [example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/cifar-recipe.ipynb)
See http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq.html#what-is-the-relation-between-mxnet-and-cxxnet-minerva-purine2
Thanks for the lightening-quick reply :)
The path error is fixed by #168
cc @hotpxl

I am sadly to say, removing `inline` does not work. The two pointer adress are still different.

When `set_value` method is registered:
![qq 20150928212643](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3897999/10136548/af853fd0-6627-11e5-923a-76d91904d604.png)
When the `fsetvalue` is called from python:
![qq 20150928212704](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3897999/10136549/b17ecd92-6627-11e5-92e9-b933283ec4e2.png)

I have written some codes to replace the function pointer with std::function, however, in an inelegant way:
https://github.com/happynear/mxnet/blob/windows/include/mxnet/ndarray.h#L465
https://github.com/happynear/mxnet/blob/windows/src/ndarray/ndarray.cc#L508

I know you guys will find a better solution. I am waiting for it.

OK, this could due to a fact that MSVC do not interpret function as function pointers I have pushed a change in https://github.com/tqchen/mxnet/commit/516a90a68f2d19812be8199a499668833330fe45 to fix  this . Please check if that works for you after it is merged in #181
Yes it works. Thank you.

If you are interest, we would love to get your contribution to make mxnet windows compatible with minimum changes. @jermainewang is working on a CMake build script to generate windows solutions, which you may be interested in collaborating

I have sent a pull request https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/183. I created the visual studio solution with imitation of https://github.com/dmlc/cxxnet/tree/master/windows . Please check and merge it.
I also got this problem.

`mlp.py` will use `data.py` to get MNIST data automatically. In the `data.py`, we use a special script for test to download the data and it only be imported in this path. You can check `data.py` to see how it works.
We will add distributed parameter sever support soon. Currently design is easy to extend to distributed case but we don't add it yet.

Thanks for the PR. Could you work together with @jermainewang to use CMake to support Windows instead of using VSProject file directly? Also please fix the issue reported in https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/builds/82698412
All dmlc projects are designed to be portable. If you see related project like xgboost, they are readily run on YARN, which means on most spark cluster which runs on YARN.

@happynear  Thanks for the contribution! We are looking into using cmake to generate the VS solutions so that it can be easier for configuration and migration, do you have experience on that to see if it is feasible?
- Ideally, we want two types of builds, one with CUDA support, another without.

You should be able to change the optimizer behavior easily by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py#L85

Consider to submit a PR on this :)

Thanks for letting us know We figure out a bug in initialization and we are fixing it. To set params for model, you may find this doc to be useful.  https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/model.html
Was caused by inconsistent scale xavier initialization. Batchnorm makes things scale invariant so it poses a less problem
I changed default Initializer, Now it works on many nets without BN. Could you try again?
Because `get_data` is imported from relevant path, you need go into folder `example/mnist`, then run `python mlp.py`
same to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/188

two 780ï¼Œmxnet is 64batchï¼Œso each gpu 32batchï¼Œ cxxnet is 20 batch eachï¼ˆI modify the cxxnet so it can run 20batch on 3GB memoryï¼‰

Normally you cannot expect mxnet to be faster than cxxnet in all cases as cxxnet is already heavily optimized in c++. But you can expect they run at same performance, with mxnet more memory efficient and more flexible.

You proposal seems to be valid, please open a PR on this

Tianqi
check out https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/imagenet has been updated
well, when I run the same inception-bn on purineï¼Œand it run 50 sample per sec

hmm, maybe you can try set `update_on_kvstore=True` http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/model.html#mxnet.model.FeedForward.fit  which will change default behavior. But I do not have tried 780 before so don't know if that would really help :)
Sorry `update_on_kvstore=False`
pls update the doc part
